article:
[[GWR 6000 Class|King]] class locomotive]]

A 'steam locomotive' is a railway locomotive that produces its power through a
steam engine. These locomotives are fueled by burning some combustible material,
usually coal, wood or oil, to produce steam in a boiler, which drives the steam
engine. Both fuel and water supplies are carried with the locomotive, either on
the locomotive itself or in wagons pulled behind.

Steam locomotives were first developed in Great Britain during the early 19th
century and dominated railway transportation until the middle of the 20th
century. From the early 1900s they were gradually superseded by electric and
diesel locomotives.
headings: The end of steam in general use
